2aJlJJUYbRy4HJ9YVvbpXw.text: I liked it I guess. We queued for quite a while - I overheard  a couple of people saying that the sundaes didn't work as the flavour of the bean overpowered the matcha, so I decided to simply go for a soft serve cone. I wanted to go for half vanilla, half matcha - I was told I wasn't allowed - although I don't see why not but anywho! I did like the matcha soft serve. Although I think this place is definitely overhyped. They must have to add a lot of sugar for it to mask the bitterness of the matcha, so I can't imagine it's actually that healthy. Don't think I'll be queueing here again any time soon.

Ry-Bb8fkavY8pf0_sGrppg.text: Green tea ice cream or matcha ice is a Japanese ice cream flavor. This flavor is extremely popular in Japan and other parts of East Asia.. The shop is nice as well as decor .. Even their chairs are green.. I took there best seller ( Crispy ) it's matcha ice cream + crispy + red beans and a cute round biscuits on top .. It's yuuuumy ... Staff are friendly and lovey ..Like it

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

SbCSecH8ds3xNcKXn1dX5Q.text: Purchased the green tea sundae with chiffon cake, red bean and cornflakes. Not that big fan of the cake as it was a bit dry but the rest was okay. Not much seating so get takeaway to avoid the crowd when it gets too busy. A good place to go if you want some green tea ice cream fix.

WSvmJ9XS68shpcYm51SWmg.text: Was very excited when knowing this opened in London. Took me awhile to go and try. We were there on a Saturday afternoon. They were busy. A lot of ppl in the tiny shop. Queue was within the shop. There are not many seat in the shop. Shop was full with customer but only 2 staff were working. One take order and another person prepare the ice cream. The person took a bit long to take an order. I ordered one of the classic matcha sundae and Houjicha Float with vanilla ice cream. I like all the topping on the sundae but I find the matcha taste can be stronger. Houjicha float which I find it quite special. It is crushed ice with Japanese rice tea flavour and top with sundae. Personally I prefer stronger matcha taste so I find Tombo matcha sundae is better. But if you prefer lighter matcha taste then this shop will be perfect for you.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

0G_bXKQEs6okdgdsuU98mg.text: New place by the edge of china town - a place for all matcha lovers! Their matcha ice cream is amazing with just the right amount of sweetness. There's a variety of things on their menu but the sundaes seem to be the most popular

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Sundaes

2MTBeaWtE017cdnMtkBL6Q.text: Disappointing experience. I absolutely loved and raved about the Kyoto location but this was nowhere near that standard. The green tea soft service was icy, the red beans were hard, and the cake was just no good. So much disappointment and to top it, more expensive than the branch in Kyoto. The only thing going for it was decent service speed.

ptCEIrNdu-yZWQwowLQNlA.text: Very refreshing desserts. I ordered the ice blended green tea. I am no matcha green tea expert, but it tasted a bit cheap.

k1ZgxuLU2Kgblj9rEak4pw.text: Love love love matcha green tea in any forms... I have tried the Matcha sundae #2 that comes with a dollop of red beans (my another favourite) in between and 3-4 mini rice balls.  Not a big fan of the rice balls, too hard to chew and tasteless. I'm a happy camper with anything green tea and red beans, the perfect combination.Back to the ice cream, it is so creamy and perfect flavour, not too bland, not too strong. Of course the price is quite expensive for that small sundae, would be more attractive if the price goes down a bit.  It was quite packed when we walked in last Monday around noon time, the shop is small to begin with and has limited seating areas.  Waited for almost 15-20 minutes for my order and finally my order came through... Unfortunately it was watery, my match green tea already melted (gosh!).. Not sure what had happened behind the scene, guess the machine not doing its work as usual. Luckily the lady who serve me apologise to me big time and said please allow her to make me another one. There you go, great customer service always receive a good rating.  I love how attentive the ladies are, preparing the tea and sundae with a lot of patience and smile. Keep it up and do pop by when you are around SOHO area, London.

2fN2lrajdhi7j7-w2vb8YQ.text: Having tried them in Taipei and Kuala Lumpur, we of course were there to support them on their grand opening day in London. Yes it was slightly disorganised in terms of ordering and payment process. However let's not forget the reason to get excited over the first Matcha soft serve ice-cream in London Soho. We have tried 5 different desserts (from sundae to floats) our favourite is the O-Matcha Sundae. A layered sundae that was absolute heaven. At the bottom is a layer of genmai; crispy toasted rice (what you'd get with genmai tea), next is a layer of red bean paste and topped with a swirl of the matcha soft ice cream. You also get a mini shiratama (glutinous riceball), a sweet preserved chestnut and a crispy waffle. All the different flavours worked so well together and the toasted rice pieces added another texture and depth of flavour to the sundae. Did we mention their matcha ice cream is intensified with matcha flavour while maintaining its smooth creaminess from the ice cream? Yum.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. http://yummyjubbly.com/tsujiri-soho-london/
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. http://yummyjubbly.com/tsujiri-soho-london/

wh6NjfYsjEzuQEKPzL8rMw.text: Got a matcha sundae or something similar.. It was really good but pretty overpriced for what it is

ZaXHM4wQS-IzVuuSE0k7ng.text: Love mocha, love the sticky rice balls!!! Must say the ice cream is too sweet for me. Visited 3 times, always want to come back

zZiZuRVbF4eA9NIPonKPGg.text: The Houjicha float tastes so good!!!!! It's really suitable for people who really like strong tea smell. It's a perfect combination with the matcha-ice-cream. Happy to find this nice Japanese tea dessert shop here. It will be much better if the shop can be bigger and more seats there.

WgQvVHRwC-nyClRzGdLLwA.text: I ordered the matcha yuzu float. The matcha part (ice cream) was very strong and delicious. They failed with the yuzu part since it's weaker than I expected and there were still big chunks of ice on the bottom. I minus one star for that reason plus for the price (quite pricey for a small portion). Nonetheless, it's still a refreshing combo eating the two together: the creamy herbal matcha really compliments the citrusy yuzu.

oeNNIFbasFpBrtftWBB1cw.text: I'd bookmarked this place to try for awhile and we managed to accidentally pass by it the other day, so we had to stop by and try it. We had the Tsujiri sundae. The matcha soft serve was probably the best quality matcha ice cream I've had anywhere! I would definitely come back for it. I didn't particularly care much for the rest of the sundae, as I personally don't like red bean much. The rice krispies at the bottom were nice, but hard to eat as I choked on them from the dryness sometimes. Unfortunately, a plain soft serve cone is 3.95, which is way too expensive in my opinion. The other menu items are decently priced, but I would rather just enjoy the matcha ice cream. I'd come here again to treat myself, but this is too expensive for frequent visits.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

1oQhXTHbsR0bxTHLruBLhg.text: Stumbled upon this matcha shop while searching for gelato and decided I no longer wanted gelato. What a great decision because the matcha sundae was delicious! Who would have known London would have matcha the closest to what I've experienced abroad in Asia?! My only complaint was that the machine at the time (due to the high demand) didn't have enough time to allow the matcha soft serve to set up, so the soft serve melted instantly. The flavors were still there though, so so make the trip here! So good, I almost went twice!

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

Ea04KckUbbnsaEmUpUBfbQ.text: I'd give it a full five stars if the portions weren't so small. Tsujiri matcha soft serve sundaes are phenomenal - especially when packed with a layer of Rice Krispies/Cornflakes (who knew this was such a magical combination? And yet, it makes so much sense ...) and a generous dollop of red bean paste. I tried both the sundae and the Houjicha Milk Float, which had a lovely roasted tea flavor. Staff are friendly and service is prompt - we received our order pretty much immediately after placing it, despite the busy hour! Downsides? Small portions and even smaller seating area ... some people had clearly finished their ice cream, but were just ... chilling (no pun intended). Which is cool, except for the fact that there's very limited seating and my friend and I just wanted to stay and chat. And order more.Still, if you've got a craving for a matcha treat, Tsujiri is a great bet. Just make sure to save up your pennies.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. The Houjicha Milk Float. SO much yum. Very refreshing.

DNcmds--t0RC13X_bME5SA.text: Since Tsujiri's opening of the London branch I have been a few times, simply because of the central location in soho and late opening hours.For the first visit I opted for the matcha sundae with chiffon cake, red bean paste and cornflakes.  The matcha soft serve is much sweeter with a creamier texture than the ice cream at Tombo or Kanada-ya.  Friends who ordered other sundaes found that the mochi were hard rather than soft and chewy.  The sundaes consisted mostly of cornflakes or rice crispies with a small serving of matcha ice cream.  On subsequent visits I tried the ice cream floats as eating breakfast cereal late at night is rather unappealing.  The bitterness of the Hojicha balanced the sickly sweet matcha ice cream so it seemed that the ice cream floats were preferable to the sundaes.  That is until my 3rd and final visit, I ordered a matcha red bean float.  The red beans were hard, the tea looked and tasted like water leftover from soaking the red beans.  A very disappointing and waste of £5.95 for an unpalatable drink.  With the recent opening of further matcha ice cream outlets there are far better options in Soho and Covent Garden.  Tsujiri needs to improve to keep up with newer competition.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Matcha red bean float 5.95
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. O-matcha sundae 4.95, Matcha houjicha milk float 5.95
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Chiffon cake sundae - matcha soft serve with chiffon cake, red bean & lots of cornflakes!

ZgyITj8cYqCldR2SWfDkEA.text: Their Houjicha soft serve and tea is delicious. But the matcha, I would not recommend, because it is very average. It's not strong at all so you would have to get double shot or just get the Houjicha stuff.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Matcha cappuccino in the front, Houjicha soft serve in the back

JE1Et3uhjxjMG7Yve-0aPQ.text: Matchhhha Mondays! And Tsujuri is as authentic as they come originating straight from Japan. I ordered the crispy sundae which at ~£5 was a bit steep I thought considering half of it was just puffy cornflakes. I also didn't enjoy the red bean which seems to be in all their sundaes. The matcha icecream was great though! Could have had a whole tub of that!

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Matcha overload

SAzsaEw-aJ611SzMp9SCjQ.text: Japanese ice-cream: basically matcha ( green tea) flavour although they also have som vanilla. If you are not sure they are kind enough to give you a small portion to try. I tried and I loved it, so I went for a sundae with rice crisps, bean paste and a rice ball. The rice ball doesn't taste much but the rice crisps give the ice cream a nice texture. I wasn't sure about the red beans soI asked then for less beans and more ice cream but the beans were quite nice combined with the ice-cream. I will go back!

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Matcha sundae with rice ball, chestnut, red beans paste and rice flakes.

c2O5Zt1YySfqbCh48GbJOg.text: I'm all about matcha so I'm so glad this place opened up in soho! The shop originates in Kyoto so I had high expectations and it didn't disappoint me once I had a spoon full of the matcha sundae with red bean and mochi with kinako powder. The combination was divine despite it being a bit sweet. The ice cream was nice and smooth with no nasty powdery bits that you get sometimes. I'd definitely like to go back, seating is limited but if you're eating ice cream in London winter weather prob best to be eaten indoors! They do have hot matcha drinks as well if you want to take it out :)

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

Ri_jYSUnGqhYF1UynEfpJQ.text: Hmmm interesting reviews from other reviewers. Well for one, this is not the first Matcha Soft serve in Soho. Before this we've had Kanada Ya soft serve (who also does sesame) and we've had Shackfuyu's infamous Kinako french toast with matcha soft serve!!!I came here yesterday, and got the matcha Shiromata Sundae. Queue was decent, about 7 min wait, the servers were still slow but seem to be faster than the other reviewers found when the place first opened. There were only two servers though and when you factor this in it's basically one person taking payments and one person doing the ice creams! Wasn't very happy that the person kept saying wait to your payment and goes and dishes out some ice creams and then goes back to taking your payments...Taste-wise, I would say the matcha is not really that strong and compared to the really really sweet red azuki beans and the syrup they poured in there you really didn't have a chance to taste matcha.It was a nice experience, abeit quite expensive at £5+ for a takeaway cup!

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

KCIIUOxbxXOcdtOKZWy0Ow.text: Having high expectations that this was a Tsujiri offshoot, I went in with the mistaken belief that the matcha desserts would actually taste like matcha, despite my gut telling me that all Japanese food in London becomes complete rubbish by association [with the food reputation].-- sounds harsh but after squeezing room in a packed itinerary to stop by Tsujiri, I was left in disbelief at how unbelievably bad everything tasted, despite looking promising from the pictures. If you have been to the original Tsujiri in Kyoto, saying that you'll be disappointed by the inauthenticity here is a kind, vast understatement.For one, the only semblance to matcha in any of the drinks or desserts here is on the outside: congrats, you've got the bright green part down. Oscar the grouch (ironically also in a trash can) would be so proud. Question: Why are the parfaits, a.k.a. "sundaes" so icy? We couldn't even figure out how to get soft-serve ice-cream, creamy? Not just taste (everything is weirdly sweet in all the wrong places) but textures are really off here. I wish I could actually stop remembering the bland white globs of the supposed "shiratama dango" that were still frozen. They are supposed to be chewy soft, not the crunchy flavorless mess you are left gnawing on. The drinks are sadly terrible too. Let's not get started on the failure that is the "o-matcha cappuccino." What an affront to both the tea and coffee industry, simultaneously. A rare one-star rating for actually offending my taste buds and tricking me into thinking that this franchise would live up to its namesake. However, it has always been a dream of mine to use the British phrase: "completely rubbish" so thank you for that.

Bsl5j-mXx8QQ0ykCp6ahEg.text: I had the matcha ice cream parfait number 1 with rice puffs, anko paste, matcha ice cream, sweet chestnut, mochi and waffle biscuit. It was a really nice treat though a little pricey but you get a generous amount that is more than enough for one person so I would recommend sharing with a friend. The matcha ice cream was the stand out for me I thought it was really good and would definitely come back to get just a soft serve cone any day!

a76KJu3RMJIx0l_XGaFv1Q.text: Love it. I'm so glad we were lost and I spotted the word matcha. My friend ordered the o'matcha cappuccino and I ordered the green tea soft serve. The serving was huge! They put the cappuccino in a huge bowl and the matcha taste was so strong. Boy do I love matcha. The soft serve was also spot on. If you never had matcha before, you should try it here. Great customer service too.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. O'matcha cappuccino
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Green tea soft serve

Tn8BaW49uH121Tf_EAvldw.text: Tsujiri- A pretty new matcha dessert bar opened in Rupert Street selling overpriced soft whipped matcha ice cream, floats and desserts. But the satisfaction you get is priceless. I love the bright modern contemporary decor. It's airy and bright keeping to the white and green theme of its vanilla and matcha flavoured desserts. Although I do hope they open up a bigger branch soon as there is very limited seats and space making it very cramp and hard to navigate in and out of the place.Personally I would avoid visiting for ice cream when it rains as you might end up eating it outside in the rain. Ren had to stand opposite to where I was sitting as although there was an empty space at the table, there was no seat there. Bad organisation.Service was friendly at least. We decided to get two very different matcha flavours desserts to try more of the menu. They do hot drinks and hot desserts too but we weren't interested that day as the sun was out.Yuzu O-matcha floatI did love that strong sweet sour citrus taste of the yuzu. It had a nice subtle hint of bitterness too making it all very refreshing. However I didn't believe the matcha float was a good pair as the acidity starting to eat away at the ice cream breaking down the milk protein from the water content, making it lose its milkiness and instead created little blobs of protein to float around. Not a beautiful sight.The matcha ice cream was amazing though before it melted into the yuzu. It was incredibly smooth and creamy on the tongue as it melted yet very light unlike regularly ice cream that can be sickly. The matcha flavour was strong enough to taste it but blended in milk and cream, the bitterness was balanced out. Very pricey for a large at £5.95 and no where near as impressive as the sundae coming up next.O-matcha chiffon cake sundaeI would definitely get this again but at £4.95 it would probably be a well deserved treat as it was pretty small. The lovely soft milky matcha ice cream soaking into the pandan cake created a lovely saturated spongy texture, bringing in the matcha flavour to the pandan. The red bean paste aided in a nice sweetness as well as a more dense and fluffy texture to give it some substance. Cornflakes was a thoughtful idea to add a nice light crunch to it. Delightful!I'm very happy that matcha desserts has finally made its way into London and slowly becoming a trend. Tsujiri is very authentic and the closest in both texture and taste compared to the ones I've had in Japan. At the moment it's a bit hectic due to it being new and trending and also because of its small space. Hopefully they will open another branch soon with more seating area.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Interior

Z9ANZ8B8yc4ecG4J-_t-nQ.text: A curiously busy new cafe with a matcha focus.  I thought it was a cute concept and was keen to try it.  The matcha soft-serve was lovely and I had a latte as well (which pretty much tasted like I make it at home ;) My date had never had matcha before and was pleasantly surprised at how mellow the flavour is. I do wish there was more 'anglo' explanation on the menu for what the options were, and also some chocolate combos, but I will definitely come back and try one of the sundaes!  Great addition to Soho :D

2BWaJKnk7ULd26i_X3ariA.text: Matcha Ice Cream Sundaes No3 with chiffon cake, red beans and cornflakes. (£4.95) This is a really yummy dessert with really nice and strong good quality matcha taste in the ice cream. However I eat quite slow as I love to savour every bite so by the time I ate half way through the cup it turned into milkshake.  :)

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Matcha Ice Cream Sundaes No3 with chiffon cake, red beans and cornflakes. (4.95)

nwS98tkLjfeShHLrhQ35Nw.text: I came here on the third day of its opening and it was pretty disorganized. The store is tiny so everyone was cramming inside to queue. I ordered the chiffon cake sundae with matcha ice cream and kinako topping and they forgot the kinako. The matcha ice cream is great but the serving is small. Maybe I'll come back when they iron out the kinks.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Chiffon cake sundae- Matcha sundae with red bean and matcha cake

RMc3np4H_0FAm7jP4u30pQ.text: Tsujiri is a Japanese traditional tea brand which serves its matcha (green tea) tea in variety of desserts and drinks. It is originated in Japan and has branches in other part of the world i.e. Singapore, Canada....The London shop is small which is located in the Soho. There are only a few seats which are usually filled during the busy hours. But when there is so many people it can get stuffy that you would rather just eat on the street.Tsujiri is popular for their soft serve ice cream which comes in two flavours, Matcha (£3.95) or Vanilla (£3.45) in either a cone or cup. You can also opt to add toppings for additional charge - Kinako (roasted soy beans powder), Red Bean, Kuromitsu (dark sugar syrup), Shiratama (mochi), Marron Glace (sugar syrup chestnut candied).If you want some thing a bit more fancy than the Matcha Sundae is a good choice. There are three to choose, Crispy Sundae (£4.95), Shiratama Sundae (£5.45) and Chiffon Cake Sundae (£4.95).The Chiffon Cake Sundae consist of corn flakes, a piece of green tea chiffon cake, red bean paste and of course matcha soft-serve ice cream.If you are like me who some time want a drink but still want an ice cream than the float (Small £5.45/Medium £5.95) is a good option. There are six to choose, O-matcha float, Houjicha float, Yuzu float, O-matcha milk float, Houjicha milk float and Red bean float. All of them comes with a choice of vanilla or matcha ice cream. It is definitely a good choice to get cool in the warm weather.There are also a variety of drinks including hot or cold ice tea and latte. For some thing to cool down in the warm weather but more on the icy side than the ice blended (Medium £3.95/Large £4.45) could be the one.

84ssP-QEzsSchRBhcbKTUA.text: These hours are posted incorrectly. They actually close at 10pm during the week and til 10:30 on Fridays and Saturdays.What a waste of a trip.

jPxuCT3aP3lPtF1GY-toxw.text: This place is dedicated to matcha flavoured desserts (and some yuzu!) and does it so very well! It has a small shop front with around 15 seats. It serves up a number of Japanese styled hot and cold drinks and a great selection of Japanese desserts! The Matcha Shaved Ice is absolutely amazing! The matcha ice cream is very smooth with strong match flavour (extremely hard to find!), the shaved ice is also matcha flavoured and both have just the right level of sweetness! Topped with mochi, red bean paste and a sweet chestnut... delicious!! Even the husband is addicted to it. Very highly recommended, personal favourite matcha desserts around London!

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

RJuHC85znvJWEfAQXM2XnA.text: I walked passed Rupert street a lot times and saw the changing of Japanese restaurant replaced with Tsujiri dessert shop. The shop offered a variety of choices, it has fresh tea; ice blended; latte; matcha/ vanilla float; sundae; cone ice cream and shaved ice. I personally not into matcha(green tea pwder) that much although it seem to get very popular in this shop. I tried the vanilla taste of sundae instead.it called shiratama sundae which cost about £4.95 compare to mc donald sundae only £1.29. The matcha shiratama cost £5.45. Only difference is the red bean and the topping. The price is over the top but the portion serving is too small and yet it attract a lot of Chinese students to hanging out here. Even the cone soft ice cream cost £3.95. I guess it new opening and summer season draw the crowd in. I guess it will take me a long time to revisit the shop again. And most of my friends agree that it is hard to earn my money .

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

Ht9eMQTtq_vw4esdtNU6uQ.text: Love the matcha and hojicha ice cream here - so delicious, not too sweet, and they offer mochi, matcha creme brulee, and a host of other delicious items on their menu.This is a must visit for matcha addicts and I'm so glad I found it since I tried to stop by Yumchaa in King's Cross and it was closed (sad!).

qA3FVI_DSzs8_jZ7EyB3CQ.text: A little hard to find (especially if you're a tourist and easily lost), and not much seating inside especially during busy hours. I got the Shiratama Matcha Sundae in a cup (had Kinako, red bean paste, Shiratama...etc.) It was about £4.95 Overall I liked my experience - patient staff, fast service, and I was satisfied with my order.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

hlBJqLCAHfVfWi1YFxl_1g.text: Tsujiri is a small dessert takeaway shop that features everything matcha and houjicha. My friend and I came here on a Friday night to get dessert after having Korean nearby. The shop probably seats about five people so most people don't stay for long or get their desserts to go. After perusing through pictures on Yelp, my friend and I both got the matcha sundae. The matcha flavor is strong and delicious! Within this cup of sundae is also a ton of other flavors and textures from the red bean paste, wafer, mochi, chestnut and rice puffs at the bottom. I loved getting a bit of everything in each spoonful!The prices are also pretty standard for the area. If you love matcha, then you need to check this place out!

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Matcha sundae

vNA4YIRv2gvPKGilVPaoRQ.text: I love this place! I've tried it before in Taiwan and no other dessert place has as strong of a matcha flavor as this chain.I always order the sundaes because I love the texture combination of soft serve, mochi, and puffed rice. Even the waffle thats printed with Tsujiri on the top of the soft serve tastes delicious. The soft serve itself is creamy, delicious, and bright in flavor. Both the Matcha and the Houjicha are great flavors. You can now get two flavors in one sundae so I recommend doing that if you want to try each one!Overall, I highly recommend this place if you're in the mood for an Asian dessert! I've never been to another dessert place that tastes so naturally match flavored as this store,

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Matcha Sundae

G_JiZcZRajNqe4FwMcLpOg.text: I was really looking forward to coming here especially after seeing the large menu of all matcha based items. I felt I couldn't go wrong, but perhaps I took a slight wrong turn somewhere.The afternoon rush seemed to quiet as I ordered so I was able to find a window seat. It took nearly 10 minutes for my order to be ready. Again, there were no other orders but mine. They called out it was ready. Really? One of the three staff couldn't bring it out to me?When I went over I noticed that my medium size had doubled into what I can assume was the large. It was a giant bowl and it was steaming hot. I asked the staff for a tray and after looking for one, he just said he would bring it out. Apparently more skilled than I was at carrying hot bowls of tea.The presentation was great but after a few sips once it cooled, it was clear that bigger isn't always better. The tea to milk ratio was low and I knew I wouldn't be able to finish the drink. I needed more flavour, more umph! The other menu items look very appealing should I be back but with other matcha tea makers in the neighbourhood, that won't be anytime soon.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Giant bowl of matcha

fplBA_sEcMi07U0LbP9ZWw.text: Tasty matcha ice cream and mochi. The place is cute and quiet, an easy spot to do some work. It was a great find!

4KKhDOiyCP4cCpi7Dz6mKg.text: This is my favourite matcha place  in London, I would recommend to everyone who wants to try the REAL matcha flavour as it is in japan. Try the soft serve ice cream if it is your first time trying this flavour.There sre just few seats so it is mostly take away and a bit of queuing. Amazing place

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

7_N2fs4chhh45DFBnL9Jzw.text: Absolutely amazing. I was a bit sceptical about this places as it seemed to be more of 'go there because it's popular' kind of place but I was definitely wrong. I had the matcha soft serve and was surprised as to how strong the matcha taste was. You could tell that the used real and authentic matcha. It was perfect, not too sweet and a very smooth texture. I got a small and they certainly give you your money's worth. Can't wait to come back an try all of the other things they offer!!!!

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

cseP2uOwuz6bXTGvpz6Huw.text: Crispy matcha sandee love it. Portion is great and reasonable price!! Went on a Saturday night after dinner  the wait wasn't too long. I'll definitely go back again

OlkEbjfeUUcA2PxdTXeePw.text: Great go to spot for a quick snack or dessert. Employees are fantastic and friendly. Menu is truly authentic.  A true testimony to their history dating back to 1860... it's very clear why they've lasted this long and will continue to. Ps. Make sure you join their loyalty programme!

gL_VYdMBokJUBvoHXTcccQ.text: Love this place. The sundaes are a well balanced collection of flavours and textures. Soft called, crunchy corn flakes, creamy I've cream. The place doesn't have loads of space to sit but a great stop for dessert and drinks.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

z1kprYkk-wgeya4H1CAlcQ.text: If you're into matcha tea, red bean paste, yuzu and ice cream and/or shaved ice you're in for a treat ! We left happier than we came in, and that's what's the most important !

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

69e9zcxqTNz-i9bVf-8r2g.text: I think the ice cream had a deep matcha flavor in it. Had the matcha sundae at Tsujiri but the normal ice cream may have been better than sundae to enjoy the matcha flavor

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Matcha sundae

Bp7uriWjKth_G4SklEHO8Q.text: I love this place. Have tried it in Asia, so I was pleasantly surprised and happy when I walked by accidentally. This is a big deal people! Finally legit, authentic matcha has arrived in central London. It's really, really good!I had the Shiromata Sundae, which was delicious! And I also got a matcha soft serve in a cup. Also delish! Perfectly sweet, with a nice, rich and smooth matcha flavour. Definitely come and get some soon.I almost knocked a star off though because this place is really small and I couldn't get a spot to sit. Never fear! You can walk 3 minutes, one block away to the courtyard of Ham Yard Hotel and sit on a bench outside. Problem solved!This place gets so busy. There was a long line out the door and I had to queue for about 10 minutes. Totally worth it though! I can't wait to come back.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. Shiromata sundae. My favourite!

8KTUI0iEnEBLWwTDhjR9Jw.text: This review is strictly based on their matcha latte because that is the only thing I got to try at Tsujiri. We were walking through the Chinatown and Soho area of London and walked by Tsujiri and wanted to give it a shot. I was pretty thirsty and like a good matcha latte, so it seemed like a good fit since they seem to "specialize" in matcha. The matcha latte was a bit lacking I felt. It was on the bland side and it did not have that strong of a matcha flavor to it. I was a bit disappointed since I have definitely tried much better matcha lattes. If you must stop by, it seems the soft serve looks a lot better and that is what most people were having so I would give that a try and the latte a pass.

9ru1oJrE1FkJ2OgjI5_kZQ.text: I came here on their second day of opening so the staff were still scrambling to figure out processes (like how to accept credit cards, or what you're ordering). You could feel the stress - but there's no need for it! Tusjiri has really yummy matcha green tea ice cream and other great desserts! I ordered the Tsujiri sundae which was good - however in the future I may skip out on all the topping stuff. I felt the red bean paste was so sweet it masked the light matcha flavor of the ice cream. Next time I'll just be getting a soft-serve; this could come down to personal preference!

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

j5u59or_cYUhoCCHA4KHeg.text: Everyone is giving this place bad reviews, but honestly I think it's because they don't know/respect matcha and aren't familiar with the ingredients in the sundaes. I didn't like the hojicha sundae flavour as much as the matcha one, but the matcha one was sooo tasty! Also in terms of price, it's pretty equal when comparing sundaes across competitors (Milk Train, Chin Chin labs, Udderlicious, ... other ice cream places in soho).

pClosimvl6VWvkj0WA6FAg.text: Got the O matcha cappuccino and matcha sundae, both are good! Highly recommend the ice cream. Very fresh and good tasting, not overwhelmingly sweet. (At least for someone living in the US for a while it's not sweet ;D)

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom

HUpc1ku-CSfRd8crAqmxgg.text: My two friends and I tried all 3 of the matcha sundaes. The matcha was a good flavor, not too sweet or too bitter. Mine had a layer of red bean and also rice cake balls that had a nice chewy texture.

photos.caption: Photo of Tsujiri - London, United Kingdom. All the matcha sundaes!

ZY843MPyARjZIpGyLedGlQ.text: The matcha soft serve is decent but tasted a bit icy to me for soft serve. Portions and prices are pretty standard for the area.
